messages: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:24): wonders if it's worth dragging up the fact that WCAG is only chartered to address the needs of users with disabilities whereas HTML has to work for a wider range of people
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:26): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: yes, if you think it's worthwhile to touch the subject matter in general
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:27): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: That's what I can't decide. I don't think I will be very popular...
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:27): (but perhaps it needs to be said)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:29): PT(W) completely missed the point of my question

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:30): Then people might say that alt is primarily an accessibility feature so it needs to address the needs of users with disabilities and therefore WCAG is the right place to do that
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (16:30): I am amazed, over and over, at how little faith they have in WCAG
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:31): bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2: have you read WCAG 2.0? If you have, do *you* have faith in it?
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (16:31): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: No, but then I don't consider it a good idea either
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (16:32): (My first introduction to it was Joe Clark's article, and I haven't seen anything to dispute it)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:37): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: It's not just an accessibility feature though. It's also needed or e.g. text-only browsers
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (16:38): Are balloons 'moored' when landed or is there a different verb?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:38): bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2: it's not quite as bad as it used to be
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:38): bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2: it's still bad, though
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:38): othermaciej, yt?
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (16:39): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Bad enough that you might be better off with the samurai errata instead?

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:40): bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2: http://www.balloonlife.com/publications/balloon_life/9608/images/tetherm.gif shows a "MOORED" balloon, so that sounds reasonable
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:40): (assuming it is actually moored, not just sitting on the ground because it's too heavy to float)

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:40): bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2: bad enough that the WG chose to produce exegesis documents themselves, because the spec itself is not suitable for mortals to interpret on their own
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (16:41): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Good enough, thanks
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (16:41): I'm anticipating a new category of spec writers, the ones sitting in the balloon moored on top of the ivory tower

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:45): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: Indeed, but it sounds like that'd possibly just shift the arguments to go in a different direction, rather than actually resolving anything
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:46): http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20080819-mozilla-drags-ie-into-the-future-with-canvas-element-plugin.html
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:46): How would you make a whole tower out of ivory, unless you poached one of the Discworld elephants?
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (16:46): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: That's what we've been doing all along
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (16:47): One person agrees to one resolution, and then another one picks up a different end and starts it all over again

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:47): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Well the point that I may or not make is that you end up with different conformance requirements if your only goal is to support the disabled compared to those you end up with if your goal is to support everyone
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (16:47): I'm sure every single person on the list has said "Yeah, that would work" to at least one suggestion
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (16:47): But they never do it to the same one
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:48): e.g. WCAG seems to forbit publishing James Joyce's Uylsses in an unaltered form
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:48): s/forbit/forbid/

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:50): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: Why do people think Adobe releasing an ActionScript VM as open source has any relation to making it not totally unrealistic that Adobe would distribute Mozilla's canvas plugin with Flash? That part of the article seems totally irrelevant to me...

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:51): also the WCAG people still seem to have the attitude that people should be prepared to put an unlimited amount of effort into accessibility despite the evidence that this is not true. Designing around this assumption doesn't help accessibility but does have negative consequences on people's perception of the value of conformance requirements
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:51): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, I have no idea
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:52): (and the rest of the article is just rephrasing the three-week-old blog post)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:52): I didn't see the 3 week old blog post before
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:52): You need to subscribe to more people's blog feeds :-)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:53): I'm probably on too many already. It's difficult to keep up with everything
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:03): wonders if the whole content area of IE could be taken over by Gecko-as-ActiveX
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:07): sees http://starkravingfinkle.org/blog/2006/12/xule-what-if/
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:12): Combining the web-compatibility of Gecko with the UI of IE? That sounds like a fantastic idea
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (17:12): How long does an internet argument have to last before you can stop assuming ignorance and start assuming malice?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:15): bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2: I thought most people assumed that from the start ;)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:20): is there anyone here who understands and can explain how DOMImplementation.getFeature() and Node.getFeature() in DOM3Core are supposed to work?
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (17:22): bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2: given the length of the alt thread, I'd say at least a few years
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:29): ddd01b1de2f07d48d4953be350a7944c, the selectors api test suite needs tests for hasFeature() and getFeature()
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:30): I'm not exactly sure what getFeature() is supposed to do, besides return a copy of the object itself if the feature is implemented
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:30): and if that's all it's meant to do, then it seems quite useless
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:31): and Node.isSupported() too
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:32): and probably getDOMImplementation() too
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:32): and getDOMImplementationList()
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:32): wishes he didn't add a feature string. I didn't realise it would complicate so many things :-(
ddd01b1de2f07d48d4953be350a7944c (17:33): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: could you come up with a list of what exactly is supposed to be tested?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:36): ddd01b1de2f07d48d4953be350a7944c, I'm mailing public-webapps about it now
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:41): ddd01b1de2f07d48d4953be350a7944c, http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-webapps/2008JulSep/0436.html
ddd01b1de2f07d48d4953be350a7944c (17:43): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: what feature/version strings should I be checking for?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:45): see the spec
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:46): "Selectors-API", "1.0"
